metadata.case_name: Bajrang Bahadur Singh v. Bakhtraj Kuer

facts.text: Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh, taluqdar of Oudh, succeeded to Gangwat Estate in 1925 on death of widow of last holder; estate governed by Oudh Estates Act I of 1869.
Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh executed will dated 11th September 1929 bequeathing five properties (lists A and B in plaint) to younger son Dhuj Singh by way of maintenance for him and his heirs.
Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh died on 16th October 1930 leaving two sons: elder Bajrang Bahadur (plaintiff) and younger Dhuj Singh.
On Raja Bisheshwar's death, estate passed to plaintiff Bajrang Bahadur as eldest son under Oudh Estates Act; Dhuj Singh got only the five properties under the will.
Dhuj Singh died in 1940 without issue, survived by widow Bakhtraj Kuer (defendant).
After Dhuj Singh's death, disputes arose; plaintiff got name mutated as owner in revenue records, but appellate revenue authority set it aside and mutated in defendant's name.

Plaintiff filed Regular Suit No. 1 of 1941 in Court of Civil Judge, Bahraich for declaration of title to five properties (four taluqdari in list A, one non-taluqdari in list B); claim to list C properties abandoned during trial.
Trial court (Civil Judge, Bahraich) on 23rd October 1941 held Dhuj Singh got life interest followed by life estates to his heirs, ultimate remainder to estate holder; dismissed suit.
First appeal to Chief Court of Oudh (Misra and Wallford JJ.) in First Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1941; affirmed trial court on 4th September 1946 and dismissed appeal.
Plaintiff obtained certificate from High Court of Allahabad (after amalgamation with Chief Court of Avadh) and appealed to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Dhuj Singh got an absolute estate or only a life interest in the properties under his father's will.
If Dhuj Singh had only life interest, whether the will validly created subsequent interests in favour of his widow or heirs.
Applicability of sections 13-A, 14(b), and 22(5) of Oudh Estates Act to succession to the properties after Dhuj Singh's death.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dhuj Singh had only life interest in properties; on his death, they vested in plaintiff as heir of late Raja.
Even if absolute interest to Dhuj Singh, plaintiff entitled to taluqdari properties (list A) under s.14(b) read with s.22(5) of Oudh Estates Act as brother preferred over widow.
Successive life estates to unborn heirs impermissible; relies on Tagore v. Tagore.

respondent_arguments.text: Bisheshwar as full owner competent to dispose; will created life estate for Dhuj Singh followed by devise to his widow as personal heir.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Construction of will; Oudh Estates Act s.11

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's argument on ss.13-A,14,22(5) Oudh Estates Act not applicable if Dhuj Singh got only life interest, not absolute ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.14 applies only if legatee becomes full owner; taluqdar can create limited interests (ss.11,12 permit, subject to perpetuity).

court_reasoning.text: Will inartistic; preamble shows intent to provide for Dhuj Singh and his heirs/successors generation after generation without trouble or quarrel; Dhuj Singh absolute owner but no right of transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'absolute owner' (malik kamil) and 'generation after generation' (naslan bad naslan) indicate heritable estate but no alienation; intent for series of life estates to personal heirs of Dhuj Singh, reverting to estate on extinction.

court_reasoning.text: Restraint on alienation consistent with life estates, not repugnant to absolute ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dhuj Singh had only life interest.

court_reasoning.text: Testator intended successive life estates for Dhuj Singh's personal heirs; gift to class valid for existing persons (widow), invalid for unborn.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Tagore v. Tagore: gift to class or series valid for those in existence at testator's death.

holdings.text: Dhuj Singh got only life interest in properties under will, not absolute estate.
Will creates valid interest for existing heirs of Dhuj Singh (widow); invalid for unborn.

precedents_cited.relevance: Gift to class valid for existing persons, invalid for unborn.

statutes_cited.name: Oudh Estates Act I of 1869
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of disposition by taluqdar; conditions on transfers/bequests to specified persons; rules of succession; permits limited interests subject to perpetuity.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds Dhuj Singh had life interest under will; valid subsequent interest for his widow as existing heir; affirms lower courts' dismissal of plaintiff's suit for declaration of title.

key_quotes.text: "Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nature of estate granted to Dhuj Singh.

key_quotes.text: "the dominant intention of the testator was to make provision not for Dhuj Singh alone but for the benefit of his heirs and successors, generation after generation"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "it was not the intention of the testator to confer anything but a life estate upon Dhuj Singh"
key_quotes.speaker: court
